descriptiveTexts.text: Up front is the teacher, Jette Schega, preparing for a double period of politics, a subject on the Burg curriculum.
Schega passes out worksheets that the students turned in during the previous class and which she has now corrected.

Schega says: "A few things caught my eye. A couple times there was a term that was listed in the wrong category. The term is extremism. Some of you included it in the pro human rights category. Could someone who did so please let me know?"
Schega: "What was your reasoning?"
Later, Schega asks what the right to equal rights means.

directQuotes.text: which should actually be far in the past in Germany.

descriptiveTexts.text: The two teachers who wrote it, Max Teske and Laura Nickel, gave a lot of interviews in the weeks after publishing their letter and held a speech at a rally in front of the education authority in Cottbus.
Teske was just packing his bag when Nickel came into the teachers’ room and asked him: "Max, should we write a letter and send it to the media?"
And on the internet, it was open season on him and Nickel.
In Burg, Teske says, he was once standing together with Nickel in a parking lot when an older woman stopped her car next to them.
German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said in July that he hoped that the departure of Teske and Nickel from Burg didn’t mean that the right-wing extremists had won.
A poster about the life of Anne Frank hangs in a school hallway.
German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said in July that he hoped that the departure of Teske and Nickel from Burg didn’t mean that the right-wing extremists had won.
The Elementary and Secondary School of Burg also has a second name, that of Mina Witkojc.
In fact, Hitler’s lackeys didn’t just oppress Witkojc, they also targeted all members of the Sorb and Wend minorities, who have called the Spreewald region home for centuries.
German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said in July that he hoped that the departure of Teske and Nickel from Burg didn’t mean that the right-wing extremists had won.
Hans-Jürgen Dreger, 69, is the kind of mayor of whom people say: "He’s the kind of mayor you want to have."
"That’s how it is," says Dreger.
A woman greets him across her fence, saying: "Hey, Jürgen!"
Dreger says that he attends every milestone birthday in town.
"These are things you just gotta do," says Dreger.
When he walks into a café, a cycling group made up of older women calls out: "Jürgen, buy a round!"
So Dreger heads to the counter and orders six advocaats: Five for the women and one for himself.
Dreger says he had actually decided to no longer speak with journalists.
Dreger didn’t want to look at first, but then curiosity got the better of him.
Dreger gave one to a television broadcaster – 15 minutes, he says.
After the man bought the Deutsches Haus in 2020, German security officials with the domestic intelligence agency and municipal representatives came to the local council, says Mayor Dreger.
Dreger says he told them: "Now I’ve got a problem. When I get home, I have to tell my wife that we can’t go to my cousin’s 60th birthday party next week."
"Well, because he is holding his party in the Deutsches Haus," Dreger responded.
Dreger says he once spoke with the restaurant owner.

They sat down at a table and Dreger said: "I can’t have anything against you yet, because I don’t yet know what is going to happen. But if you do anything in our town that’s not nice, then you’ll get to know me."
Once, says Dreger, he rode past the Deutsches Haus on his bicycle and thought he heard chants of "Sieg Heil!"
"But I have to say, on men’s day, at the beer stand, they also chant stuff like that," Dreger says, citing the annual tradition in some parts of Germany.

And they recorded a video statement called "#WIRsindBurg,” or We Are Burg. In the four minute and 26 second video, 11 people from Burg, including Dreger, say that they are opposed to "discrimination, racism and extremism," that they stand up "for diversity" and that they "sharply condemn" what happened at the school.
Mayor Dreger is on hand, shaking hands and saying things like: "You’re here and not in Hollywood?"
The gray-haired man is named Markus Mandel, 63, and he has been Burg’s crisis manager since summer.
Mandel describes himself as a long-time resident of Burg and speaks in the local dialect.
Mandel didn’t know what the official wanted to talk to him about, only that it was important.
The man wanted to speak with Mandel about the letter that had been written by the teachers in Burg.
The school official asked Mandel to take the job of school principal.
"They hope that I’ll be able to fix things," says Mandel.
Most likely, Mandel was expected to produce that which politicians so often yearn for after a scandal: peace and quiet.
On the morning that I am sitting in his office, Mandel doesn’t have much time.
"So, you try to explain it," says Mandel.
The problem was changed, says Mandel.
"You can’t be too careful around here at the moment," says Mandel.
A clique, Mandel says.
Recently, Mandel says, he ran into a former student of his, who he had seen after graduation standing behind an information stand for the far-right extremist NPD party.
"You don’t really know what to say in such moments," says Mandel.
Later, Mandel tells the story of a second grader who had called out "Heil Hitler."
"He was sobbing the entire time. If he’s not traumatized, then I don’t know what’s going on," says Mandel.
Mandel, the school principal, called the police and had them drive into the schoolyard, with the officers then searching for clues.
"Even during East German times, we had families where grandpa made all the decisions," says school director Mandel.
On another day, I’m walking up the steps together with Mandel.
A boy says: "Look Mr. Mandel, I have a balloon."
Mandel takes it away from him and says: "At least I now know what else you can do with it."
An open letter about Hitler salutes in the schoolyard and swastikas on the benches of a school in the municipality of Burg made nationwide headlines in Germany.

The news stories that brought me here described Hitler salutes in the schoolyard, students calling out "Arbeit macht frei," the slogan the Nazis wrote on a sign at the entry of the Auschwitz concentration camp, in the classroom and restaurants run by violent hooligans.
Nine of them were showing the Hitler salute.
H is the eighth letter in the alphabet, and in neo-Nazi circles, 88 is short for "Heil Hitler."
Later, Mandel tells the story of a second grader who had called out "Heil Hitler."
In fact, Hitler’s lackeys didn’t just oppress Witkojc, they also targeted all members of the Sorb and Wend minorities, who have called the Spreewald region home for centuries.
There is the story of the teacher who, after discussing the Hitler Youth over several lessons asked the class: "So, who would still join them now?"
The boy is one of the students seen in the photo giving the Hitler salute.

Teske says that he and his colleague came up with the idea of writing an open letter after the old school principal didn’t report a Hitler salute during gym class to the school authorities in Cottbus.
For this article, we’ll call him Heinrich.
Heinrich’s next class is astronomy, which is also its own subject here at the school in Burg.
A girl calls over to Heinrich: "Heinrich, Dennis is gay, and he likes you."
Heinrich grins and says: "I know."
The teacher asks them, "don’t you have class?" and drags Heinrich back into the room.

The two teachers who wrote it, Max Teske and Laura Nickel, gave a lot of interviews in the weeks after publishing their letter and held a speech at a rally in front of the education authority in Cottbus.
On a Thursday in February, Teske is sitting in a café not far from Potsdam.

Teske says that he and his colleague came up with the idea of writing an open letter after the old school principal didn’t report a Hitler salute during gym class to the school authorities in Cottbus.
Teske was just packing his bag when Nickel came into the teachers’ room and asked him: "Max, should we write a letter and send it to the media?"
"We actually thought that it would just be a small letter to the editor," Teske says.
Teske says a group of men ran up to him.
"It almost got violent," Teske says.
That was in Cottbus, where Teske was living at the time.
In Burg, Teske says, he was once standing together with Nickel in a parking lot when an older woman stopped her car next to them.
Finally, someone here said something." Teske says that parents also came up to him on his last day of school in Burg to thank him. "There are really good people in Burg.

When we leave the café after one-and-a-half hours and climb into Teske’s car, the song "Schrei nach Liebe" (Scream for Love) by Die Ärtzte is playing, the band’s anti-Nazi song about the romantic hope that Nazis would let go of their hate if only people showed them enough love.
German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said in July that he hoped that the departure of Teske and Nickel from Burg didn’t mean that the right-wing extremists had won.
But people at the school say that other teachers who supported the letter from Teske and Nickle are now thinking of leaving town.
